Award.AwardTitle: Mitigation of Fatigue Induced Effects in Skeletal Muscle Through Closed-Loop Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) is prescribed by clinicians to aid in the recovery of strength, size, and function of the muscles of people suffering from movement disorders to enable improved mobility and activities of daily living. The research objective of this award is to enable improved rehabilitative outcomes of the NMES treatment by developing new closed-loop stimulation methods that prolong the application of stimulation by compensating for or delaying the onset of muscle fatigue. The research approach progresses from the development of NMES controllers that can compensate for diminished muscle force production and decreased responsiveness of the muscle. Developed controllers will embed a stimulation protocol in the design that indicates how to vary the intensity and frequency of stimulation to reduce fatigue. Deliverables include a class of closed-loop control methods, stability analysis tools, demonstration through human subject testing, documentation of research results, and engineering student education.

If successful, the results of this research will have the potential to enable prolonged dosage of NMES therapies by compensating for and/or delaying the onset of muscle fatigue. Longer rehabilitation sessions enabled by the ability to yield accurate limb motion from prolonged stimulation can speed the rehabilitation of people with movement disorders caused by stroke, spinal cord injury, multiple sclerosis, traumatic brain injury, etc. The mathematics and analysis tools developed to compensate for decreasing controllability effects and delayed response in muscles can also be abstracted to other engineering applications such as networked systems, telerobotics, and fault tolerance. Research outcomes will be transitioned through a transatlantic degree consortium project focused on developing engineers and scientists who can work with physicians and surgeons to develop innovative medical practice. The research challenges will be used to educate graduate and undergraduate students, and developed solutions will be disseminated through publications, conference presentations, and workshops.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) is prescribed by clinicians to aid in the recovery of strength, size, and function of human skeletal muscles to obtain physiological and functional benefits for impaired individuals. There are two primary applications of NMES: 1) rehabilitation of skeletal muscle size and function via plastic changes in the neuromuscular system, and 2) activation of muscle to elicit movements that result in functional performance (i.e., standing, stepping, reaching, etc.) termed functional electrical stimulation (FES). In both applications, stimulation protocols of appropriate duration and intensity are critical for preferential results. A fundamental barrier to NMES/FES treatments is the rapid onset of muscular fatigue during repeated contractions. In this project, new closed-loop control methods were developed to advance the state of the art in computer controlled muscle stimulation.

 

Technical breakthroughs in this project can be categorized in two main categories. One category is the use of control methods that switch between different muscle fibers to yield a desired limb motion. One impact of this breakthrough was the development of the first link between the design of how the electrical field (i.e., modulation strategy) with the effect on performance and muscle fatigue. Another impact was the development of a way to switch between different muscle fibers of a single muscle group to significantly reduce muscle fatigue, allowing more muscle contractions (i.e., greater rehabilitation dosage). This result was demonstrated in both healthy normal individuals and individuals with a spinal cord injury. A final impact of this breakthrough was the development of strategies to switch between different muscle groups to yield coordinated limb motions such as cycling. Advancements were made in motorized and non-motorized cycles that allow for prolonged cycling with more accurate coordination of the legs (an important outcome for individuals where disease affects the function of one leg). This outcome was demonstrated in individuals with Parkinson’s disease to illustrate the impacts of the work. A rehabilitation cycling small business was started by one of the graduated doctoral students that developed intellectual property related to the outcomes of this project.

The other technical breakthrough resulted from the discovery that there is a delay between when an electric field is applied to muscle and when the muscle contracts. It was further discovered that this delay gets longer as the muscle fatigues. This delay can cause undesired behaviors in rehabilitation treatments. In addition to discovering these delays, an impact of this project were stimulation strategies that could reduce the effects of such unknown and variable delays.

In addition to the broad impact of transitioning advanced control systems theory to rehabilitation science, this project afforded an opportunity for student education from K-12 to visiting international researchers. Researchers engaged in robot camps and science days at elementary and middle schools. The PI augmented the curriculum of robot merit badges to include human machine interaction for rehabilitation and then taught the modified curriculum to boy scouts across north central Florida. The PI also hosted a series of French exchange students that each wrote master theses focused on the outcomes of this project, and also hosted yearlong visits by Japanese researchers that transplanted the technology to Japan.
